conversation.text: Hi there, friend. Great to see you again. Would you want to make creamy pudding with me tonight?

recipe.title: How to Make Creamy Pudding
steps: Combine the milk, salt, sugar, and vanilla bean.
Whisk together the cornstarch and remaining milk.
descriptions: Combine 2 cups (500 ml) of milk with the full amount of salt, sugar, and vanilla bean seeds in a medium saucepan. Place the saucepan on the stove over medium heat and bring the mixture to a gentle simmer, stirring frequently. To maximize the richness of this pudding, use whole milk. Other varieties of milk will also work, however, including low-fat dairy milk, non-fat dairy milk, almond milk, and soy milk. If you are using an actual vanilla bean for this recipe, split it open and scrape the seeds directly into the mixture during this step. If you are using vanilla extract, though, do not add it now; add it alongside the butter during a later step.

In a separate small bowl, whisk together the cornstarch with the remaining 1/2 cup (125 ml) of milk. Continue whisking until the cornstarch dissolves and the slurry seems smooth. If there are any lumps in the cornstarch slurry, those lumps will end up getting into the pudding, too.

Place the egg yolks in the cornstarch slurry and lightly beat them into the slurry using the whisk. Use only the separated egg yolks and not the full eggs. If you choose to use liquid egg yolks instead of freshly separated yolks, measure out 2 Tbsp (30 ml) and beat them into the cornstarch slurry as usual.

Remove the saucepan from the heat once the milk begins to boil. Slowly pour the cornstarch slurry into the saucepan, whisking well and continuously to combine. Since the cornstarch slurry has egg yolk in it, you need to work carefully so that the egg yolk does not over-coagulate and curdle. Adding the egg yolk slowly, thoroughly whisking as you add it, and keeping the entire mixture away from direct heat should help prevent curdling. As you whisk in the cornstarch slurry, the pudding should already start thickening.

Return the saucepan to the stove and reduce the heat to low. Bring it to a gentle simmer and cook the pudding for another minute or two after that point. Stir frequently as the pudding continues cooking to prevent skin or lumps from forming. This step should cook the egg yolks and cornstarch, causing the pudding to thicken up further. When ready, the pudding should be thick enough to coat the back of a metal spoon without running off.

Remove the saucepan from the heat again. Add the butter to the pudding, mixing well to incorporate it. If using vanilla extract instead of an actual vanilla bean, add the vanilla extract to the pudding during this step, as well.

If the pudding seems lumpy, you can push it through a strainer to catch and remove any lumps. Collect the smooth pudding in a medium to large bowl placed beneath the strainer. This step can get messy and it isn't always necessary. If you don't think there are any lumps in your pudding, or if you don't mind biting into a few, consider skipping it.

Cover the pudding with plastic wrap and refrigerate it for about 2 hours, or until it feels cool. Spoon it into individual serving dishes and enjoy. Note that you could also enjoy this pudding warm or at room temperature if desired. It should be thick enough even prior to refrigeration.

conversation.text: Sure, sounds good. What should I do to get started, sir?

Go ahead and combine your salt, sugar, vanilla beans and milk all into a medium saucepan. Then, turn the stove up to medium heat and place the saucepan on the stove. If you like rich pudding, I would suggest using whole milk.
evidence: Combine 2 cups (500 ml) of milk with the full amount of salt, sugar, and vanilla bean seeds in a medium saucepan.
Place the saucepan on the stove over medium heat and bring the mixture to a gentle simmer, stirring frequently.

conversation.text: Hmm, I like whole milk. I think I'll be using that.
Now grab a small bowl and combine your 1/2 cup of milk and cornstarch all together. Use a whisk to mix it together.
evidence: In a separate small bowl, whisk together the cornstarch with the remaining 1/2 cup (125 ml) of milk.

conversation.text: Sorry, sir! Wait. How much sugar, salt and vanilla beans and milk did I need to use before?
conversation.chosenReferece: Ok, got it. Are we almost done?

conversation.text: Oh, sorry about that! You will need 2 cups of milk, 1/8 tsp of salt, 1/2 cup sugar, 1 tsp vanilla extract OR 2 inch vanilla bean.
Alright. Got it. Should I do everything at once, or do each item separately?
conversation.chosenReferece: Alright. Got it. Should I do everything at once, or do each item separately?

conversation.text: Do each item separately, carefully and precisely.
Ok. I have everything I need. Is there any more information I need to know?
conversation.chosenReferece: Ok. I have everything I need. Is there any more information I need to know?

conversation.text: Nope! Now you can go ahead and grab a small bowl and combine your 1/2 cup of milk and 3tbsp cornstarch all together. Use a whisk to mix it together.
evidence: In a separate small bowl, whisk together the cornstarch with the remaining 1/2 cup (125 ml) of milk.

conversation.text: Ok. Done. What should I do next, sir?
Pour 2 egg yolks into the small bowl (with the milk and corn starch) and beat them using a whisk. Make sure to add only the yolks.
evidence: Place the egg yolks in the cornstarch slurry and lightly beat them into the slurry using the whisk.

conversation.text: There we go. Now what?
Take the saucepan off of the heat and pour your cornstarch mix in the saucepan. Continue whisking it efficiently and well.
evidence: Remove the saucepan from the heat once the milk begins to boil. Slowly pour the cornstarch slurry into the saucepan, whisking well and continuously to combine.
Since the cornstarch slurry has egg yolk in it, you need to work carefully so that the egg yolk does not over-coagulate and curdle.

conversation.text: Ok, I got it. Should I leave it on the heat for a little longer now, sir?

Yes, exactly. Leave it on the heat for about 1-3 minutes and turn down the heat to low. Wait until it reaches a very light simmer and continue stirring to avoid lumps and skin forming in your pudding.
evidence: Return the saucepan to the stove and reduce the heat to low. Bring it to a gentle simmer and cook the pudding for another minute or two after that point.

conversation.text: Hmm, okay. There aren't any visible lumps or skin. What next, sir?
Take the pan off of the heat once more and add in your 1 tbsp of butter into the mix. Once again, continue whisking.
evidence: Remove the saucepan from the heat again. Add the butter to the pudding, mixing well to incorporate it.

conversation.text: This sounds like a recipe for a creamy pudding. What's next?
conversation.chosenReferece: This sounds like a recipe for a creamy pudding. What's next?

conversation.text: Now I have a question for you which will determine the next step. Does your pudding seem lumpy?
Hmm, nope. It doesn't. Does this mean we don't need to strain it?
conversation.chosenReferece: Hmm, nope. It doesn't. Does this mean we don't need to strain it?

Yes, exactly! You are a professional at this. At this point, you can cover your pudding with plastic and leave it in your fridge for 1-2 hours, or up until it reaches a chilled state. You can enjoy this pudding warm or cool. Enjoy, and I hope to see you again soon.
